page.title: 11 Langley Fitzurse School
page.content: { Langley Fitzurse School}is the village school in Kington Langley, taking its name from that of the ecclesiastical parish.{Reginald {Fitzurse}was one of the knights involved in the murder of Thomas a Becket. For this deed Henry II who was king of that time (1170) gave him some land which is now Kington Langley. As the school took its name from Reginald Fitzurse, the school's badge is Reginald's crest: three bears' heads on a yellow background. The school is built of Cotswold stone and the original buildings were erected in 1856. Enlargments on the school were done in 1969 and 1984. The school has a main building with two classrooms added and there is a mobile as well. There are 90 pupils.
